“If anything, I hope you can find a renewed appreciation for those people in your tribes, the ones closest to you, and the ones who have gotten you to this point. And will get you to all the places you want to go.” #JHU2020
“Those things are the same things that we as a species had hundreds of thousands of years ago when our little tribes weren't connected by follows or up-votes, or likes.”

“This world is going to be different, but there are still constant threads that will stay the same no matter what. No matter what changes technologically, no matter what changes economically, no matter what changes societally…”

“For people who teach you to be more patient, or whose qualities you admire, or whose baking skills you wish to learn from. Whatever those things are, those people have such a disproportionate effect on your happiness, on your overall outcome, that it's worth optimizing.”
“At the end of the day, the people you spend your time with will have a disproportionate impact on your life and your wellbeing. And you should absolutely optimize for people who make you better.”

“In every circumstance that I have gotten into, I've been comforted by the fact that I, know I don't know everything. None of us do. Anyone who acts like they do is just lying. We're all figuring out as we go along.” @alexisohanian
“You are in a very, very special group of graduates. You are among some of the elites in this country, and you have a responsibility. We all do.” @alexisohanian

“Frankly, failure, setbacks, disappointments, they're all going to be a part of your life. Up until this point…all of your education has been about not failing. That's how you got here: by avoiding failure. And yet there’s no more syllabus.”

“The best thing you can do right now is be adaptive. The strongest entrepreneurs all share this same quality. It's an ability to adapt to circumstances that you cannot control and focus your energy on changing the things and improving the areas you can.” @alexisohanian

“I know this is not the graduation you all were hoping for and it's just not the same. But it's your ability to adapt to the ruined dreams of your graduation that are the exact skills that you will need right now.”

Next up in our virtual Commencement ceremony: @alexisohanian gives his keynote address to the Johns Hopkins University Class of 2020. #JHU2020   Tune in live: https://t.co/eBZaMOdlOI https://t.co/Xv7KZKqTbC

“We as Hopkins graduates are uniquely prepared to confront and overcome the crises we face, and to build the world we need. And I’m confident that the Class of 2020 is ready to make its mark…as soon as we’re allowed to leave our parents’ basement.” #JHU2020

“Despite the crisis of the moment, our memories of Hopkins will not be a missed graduation – they will be the happy memories of Spring Fair, the NCAA championships, the life changing professor, or, maybe, even the streakers in Brody.”

“We sacrifice to protect older generations, to protect friends with compromised immune systems, to reduce the burden on healthcare workers. We sacrifice both for ourselves and for others. But the only reason we’re here… is because of the sacrifices that others have made for us.”
“While it’s certainly understandable to be sad at the loss of the iconic graduation experience, it might not be a bad thing to graduate with the idea of sacrifice on our minds.”
Pavan Patel, President of the JHU Class of 2020, presents his remarks on what it means to him to graduate, albeit virtually, during a global pandemic. #JHU2020
"Class of 2020, this is your gift. Embrace and embody it. Head up the hill and show us all the way forward. We are so very, very proud of you. Godspeed." #JHU2020

"I know you will emerge from this moment stronger and more directed for having shouldered the weight of this time and, like Sisyphus, filling your hearts, knowing you did all you could, every day, every moment, for as long as you had to."
"...and by continuing to be of service, to our Baltimore community as well as to your own families to whom you are a source of hope for the future. And so, so much more."

"You have already begun to answer the call of this moment, by launching yourself into new research projects with your professors from thousands of miles away; by delivering stirring performances of Bach in your living room with fellow musicians from around the world..."
"But I know this: You are more than ready. You bring to this moment a remarkable capacity for problem solving, creativity, compassion and intellectual pursuit."

"There is a Yiddish aphorism that my late father shared with me when he first learned he had just a few months of life ahead of him: 'Mann tracht, un Gott lacht.'  'Man plans and god laughs.'"  Indeed one can hardly anticipate how things will unfold in fraught moments like this."

"The bottom line is: We’re not together in the way we hoped to be. So, please, if you remember nothing else from this day, remember this: Your professors and I are bereft without you, and have been since we went virtual. It is a void that no amount of Zooming can possibly fill."

"Traditionally, commencement is a time of optimism and possibility, of pomp and circumstance, as you line up by the thousands to take the stage in front of your professors, friends, and family. This year: You got this."
President Daniels now gives his remarks to the Johns Hopkins University Class of 2020 graduates. #JHU2020   Tune in live: https://t.co/ncYsCIaDvs https://t.co/NmzTkBJl2D

.@jasonfarleyJHU, an infectious disease-trained nurse epidemiologist @JHUNursing, led health care workers through safely donning PPE. At the start of each shift, workers will don PPE simultaneously, limiting cross contamination and ensuring everyone has a partner to test fit. https://t.co/xIUWGrP3fU

During a fit test conducted for training purposes earlier this month, participants donned face masks and a specialized testing headpiece. A partner then sprayed a sweetened mist into the headpiece. Wearers who smelled/tasted the spray had to adjust their masks for a tighter fit. https://t.co/6viFheE1OC

The dedicated disrobing area helps cut down on cross-contamination. The facility also contains dedicated shower facilities for health care workers to use at the end of their shifts. https://t.co/EonlLowXI3
The field hospital contains specified rooms for health care providers to don and remove PPE. The donning room pictured here contains the necessary PPE and related supplies. https://t.co/6mdLTwZTRU

The 10’x10’ patient bed area contains a medical cot, chair, bedside table, and a small footlocker for patient belongings. The space is also equipped with four electrical outlets that patients and physicians can use. https://t.co/pnAPHqqK7D

Established as part of @GovLarryHogan’s preparedness plan, the field hospital has 250 beds and 50 bed packages supplied by @fema. The hospital will be managed and staffed by employees from @HopkinsMedicine and @umms. https://t.co/62OTMGNjlS

"I have no doubt that you will bring forward ideas that – as outlandish or perhaps even impossible they may seem – will be the ones that will help us understand and improve our world – and our universe.   To our newest Blue Jays, bon voyage!" - Daniels

Daniels describes the two options that NASA engineers considered to land humans on the moon -- and then return them. Direct ascent vs. orbital rendezvous. Brilliant engineers and scientists argued their case for each.  "Rendezvous won the day...and the rest is history." https://t.co/UdChQq6W9a

Daniels begins telling the story of President JFK's challenge (the assignment!) to the nation to go to the moon.   "And completing it would require thousands of people from different backgrounds and different disciplines in different locations to work together." - Daniels
"Tonight, I want to put your minds at ease! Because, trust me, no matter how challenging, how intimidating, your first assignment will be – it could be worse. Much worse." - Daniels

"You might be wondering what your first assignments will be – the first big paper, the first exam, or perhaps most demanding, the first group project with a new cohort in which your fate rests in the hands of the collective." - Daniels

"It is a time of great excitement and perhaps a little trepidation. I remember my first days of undergraduate life and being in what I can only describe as a constant state of terrified exhilaration. It passes. In four years – or so."  - Daniels

Vice Provost Phillips presents the new class to President Ronald J. Daniels, who begins his welcome remarks.  "Let me now welcome officially the great class of 2023 and all our great transfer students to Johns Hopkins University!"  #GoHop https://t.co/cA2asTNPvR

“If we treat people like consumers, they’re going to treat politics like cereal. But if we engage people as real agents of democracy & cultivate their capacities, there’s a hunger that people have to want to engage in public life and in shaping their communities and their world.” https://t.co/f3q4boaw1X

“As humans, we are not born with the capacities for what it takes to engage in democratic societies, but instead, those capacities are cultivated. That’s why these great free schools like the agora are so important.” #SNFDialogues
“Democracy is not just about people taking action, but it’s about people taking action in a way that actually allows them to have voice over the outcomes that they care about.” #SNFDialogues

“Part of what differentiated Athenian democracy from other city-states around classical Greece was the fact that it had this agora, this place where people who were different learned how to disagree with each other, and there was a structured forum for debate and deliberation.”

“When we think about democracy in its original formulation, it was about the capacity of people to act together. The agora was the place where people came together to develop the capacities to learn to act together in the ways they needed to make democracy work.” #SNFDialogues

"What choices can we make now in the 21st century to realize democracy's promise?"   #SNFAgora Institute Director @HahrieHan describes the power people and organizations have to cultivate civil engagement across the political spectrum. #SNFDialogues https://t.co/TXicT7vtPF

“How do we use this newfound responsibility? How do we use our education for the good of humanity? There are the easy answers. Plant a garden. Give to charity. So then, what are the hard answers? How do we create long-term sustainable change?” #JHU2019
“As students, we’re told that an education - at Johns Hopkins no less - is a privilege... and a responsibility. A responsibility to give back, to make the world a better place.” #JHU2019

“My own Hopkins experience was shaped by many things, but what stands out most are the people: my friends, my classmates and all the other bright, hardworking and dedicated individuals I met, from Orientation to Commencement.” -Zanir Habib, Class President #JHU2019 https://t.co/WnmLYb2PSa

“They can expand the circumference of your own empathy and understanding, they can clarify what inspires you. And above all they can connect you powerfully to the people who matter most. And today, graduates, YOU matter most.” #JHU2019

“As you leave here, know that the scars you carry, or will in time carry, need not diminish you. They can offer you the perspective, the strength, the equanimity to face more and do more than you ever dreamed possible.” #JHU2019
“You now know with certain confidence that the harder you pound your keyboard, the harder you’re working.” #JHU2019

@KateBradfordSci @HopkinsSports As for why they chose to adopt Lord Baltimore’s coat of arms in the first place, it probably came from the earliest designer of the University’s Seal, who went in that direction and the trustees liked it. #MysterySolved (3/3)
@KateBradfordSci The colors are also represented in the Maryland state flag. The pages shown here also explain why our @HopkinsSports teams *don’t* wear black and gold. (2/3) https://t.co/P7p35Q6AP0

@KateBradfordSci Great question! JHU archivist James Stimpert pointed us to John C. French’s "A History of the University Founded by Johns Hopkins" (1946), which explains that the colors black and gold, or “Old Gold and Sable,” were taken from the coat of arms of Lord Baltimore. (1/3)

The shield is made of a carbon-carbon composite, foam, and coated in white tungsten. It's a remarkable scientific and engineering feat, and you can learn more about it at the Hub --> https://t.co/lktw0BKVwL https://t.co/nZTUEFErgP

So how do you fly within 4 million miles of the sun and not melt into space ooze?  That's the 4 million mile question. @NASA answers in this video. (We'll give you the TL;DR next.) https://t.co/eklPyI5QwT
Thanks for the alley-oop, Venus! https://t.co/3XctRchQ3V

So how will #ParkerSolarProbe get so close to the sun?   It will use seven Venus flybys over seven years to gradually shrink its orbit around the sun, coming as close as 3.83 million miles (Earth averages about 94 million miles away). https://t.co/uC6wi6RsV6

Scientists expect the mission's findings to help us improve satellite communications, power grid issues, pipeline erosion, radiation exposure on airline flights, and astronaut safety. https://t.co/5qZLh92jFy

The mission: Explore the sun's unstable atmosphere, called the corona, as it generates solar winds, flares, & eruptions of millions of tons of magnetized material.   The hope: gain a better understanding of the "space weather" that sometimes disrupts our lives on earth. https://t.co/sQ4cTGC9D9

In April 2015, NASA approved the #ParkerSolarProbe 's mission plan, granting @JHUAPL permission to design and build the spacecraft. The APL team moved deliberately to build this new machine (though not as fast as this GIF would have you believe.) https://t.co/BWrMQpdEmq

If you missed all the hubbub yesterday about @NASA's latest pre-dawn launch, we understand. It was quite early (3:31 am). So we're going to give you a brief recap on why the #ParkerSolarProbe is so special.   Follow this #HopkinsThread to learn more! https://t.co/JdUjmjxVas

So here's what you need to know next:   The #ParkerSolarProbe launch window is scheduled to open this Sat., Aug. 11 between 3:48 and 4:48 a.m. Stay tuned for more info about the mission, & read more about the science of the heat shield here --> https://t.co/ij5jRNujQX
About 85 degrees Fahrenheit.  That's like, a nice summer day. https://t.co/fK8tPquU8u
So while the outside of the heat shield is reaching crazy high temperatures in the sun's atmosphere, guess how hot the rest of the spacecraft will get?  Come on, guess. https://t.co/VaWOWv8Wdb

The #ParkerSolarProbe has machinery that will keep the majority of the spacecraft and its sensitive instruments in the shadow of the heat shield. Using solar limb sensors (circled), the probe will self-correct its orbit in midair to keep the instruments shielded. See circled: https://t.co/Ujh96Yb4b9

Sandwiched between thin outer layers of carbon-carbon is a chunk of carbon foam, which is 97% air. The carbon foam keeps heat from transferring.   If you've read this far, here's your reward: "Blow Torch vs. Heat Shield." YESSSS https://t.co/6MhtNy6ulx

To continue: This special coating was applied to a layer of tungsten, thinner than a strand of hair, which was then applied to a 4.5-inch-thick carbon shield. Here's another look at the heat shield: https://t.co/g183HKYU7P

"I always tell people it works because it's a lousy coating. If you want to make a good coating, [the mission will] fail." --Dennis Nagle, principal research engineer for the heat shield coating.   And, of course: https://t.co/131PHfBC3f

Usually when applying ceramic coatings, you want a smooth coat, but that would shatter if exposed to this kind of heat. Instead, this coating was applied to specifically enhance porosity. When cracks form in a porous coat, they'll spread until they hit a pore + *then stop." https://t.co/sK9wZ9KYMP

The best way for the spacecraft to expel heat is to block it in the first place. To do that, scientists at @JHUAPL developed a bright white coating that will reflect heat and light in the form of photons. The coating was applied to the probe's "heat shield" -- example here: https://t.co/jmZNniT8HS
BTW, here's a closer look -- an #explainer, if you will -- at the intensity of the heat the #ParkerSolarProbe will soar towards.... https://t.co/KfBS3AJaPY

The #ParkerSolarProbe will travel to within 3.83 million miles of the sun's surface. For perspective, Earth averages about *92.96 million miles* from the sun.   (Just for fun: Doing the trip by an average car would use 3.5 million gallons of gas at a fuel cost of $10 million.) https://t.co/LrX8M5jWPo

To learn more about these and other emerging technologies being developed at Johns Hopkins, follow @HubJHU for the latest stories and news. (7/7) https://t.co/AUmqZFTfZM

Followers of prosthetic technology advances may recall that @JHUAPL is a leader in developing modular prosthetics that can be controlled by human thought (6/7): https://t.co/pP7WEeW4vd https://t.co/YMeAFzENjz

In this video from @SciRobotics, @JHUBME graduate student Luke Osborn explains this developing technology, which can differentiate between rounded and pointy objects. "It's taking one more step closer to having life-like upper limb prosetheses," he says. (5/7) https://t.co/BHTuENKTYC

In lab tests, the team showed "the ability of the prosthesis and amputee to differentiate nonpainful or painful tactile stimuli using sensory feedback and a pain reflex feedback control system." Source: @SciRobotics (4/7) https://t.co/UYvLx2RrFp https://t.co/A7zkH6b1X9

The team created a "neuromorphic model" mimicking the touch and pain receptors of the human nervous system, allowing the e-dermis to electronically encode sensations just as the receptors in the skin would. (3/7) https://t.co/eHw3UeDHLy

Made of fabric and rubber and laced with sensors to mimic nerve endings, this "e-dermis" recreates a sense of touch as well as pain by sensing stimuli and relaying the impulses back to the peripheral nerves. (2/7) https://t.co/flFnq93O3Z

Here's a quick thread on tech that Hopkins #biomedicalengineers are developing to assist amputees. It's an area of research interest and expertise that many across Hopkins, in different divisions, are working on.   Their latest work: "electronic skin." (1/7) https://t.co/I8yazJmn2A
